number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												If you like Borderlands, then you will love this game! If you hated Borderlands, you still might want to give this a try because it has everything that Borderlands lacks. Defiance is a post apocalyptic game where humans and aliens try to live in peace on a Earth that has been so vastly changed by terraforming and everything isn't completely made of tin roofs and signs. You play as an ArkHunter and your main job is to complete missions for NPCs. You can also do side missions and challenges, they are fairly fun but do get repetitive after a bit. There are also missions called ArkFalls, a gaint crystal falls from the sky and either mutants or Hellbugs are around it. After the typical 3 waves of badies are gone collect all the goodies on the ground and stuff your inventory. Its a pretty decent challenge if you play alone but its much more fun and a bit more difficult if you play with a huge group of players. If you'd like to play with a friend, its so easy to team up! I always play games where I co-op and i gotta say, this was extremely easy to connect to. For me, there is very little waiting time for things and smaller areas to load. The game play is pretty smooth although it can glitch up a bit (a main mission's enemies wouldnt appear once for us but it did come back the next day). I find the controls to be very smooth and very easy to move around. Even the driving is pretty smooth, on the road at least! you can take your vehicles off-road and its one heck of a ride. There are some ramps and cut off roads that are awesome to jump off of. Just be careful of rocks and road blocks, you'll either get stuck or explode and be ejected from you vehicle into a horde of badies.The guns aim well and are easy to control but it can be overwhelming trying to find the right gun for yourself and applying mods. Often times you'll have more weapons and grenades than you'll know what to do with. Its a bit confusing and a lot of trial and error and you will have to sell a lot of items but at least you make a lot of ingame money. Although you can buy things with real world money i really didn't see the need to spend money on in game stuff.  This game is so much fun and for the price, i feel very satisfied and to me it is very worth the money (mine was a gift though, thanks Vader!).  I usually never write reviews to games but this one truly deserves to be reconized for its great game play, good story and the amount of hours you'll spend on it.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Defiance has been fun so far, you can play alone and do missions solo or team up in a group to do them, i would say its more fun to play as a group but not totally needed. Graphics are clear enough and gameplay is easy. There are however some issues like not being able to log in, getting kicked out, game crashes but i kinda expect that these days with any online game as none are perfect, Do you have to watch the tv series before playing? i would say it helps if you want to follow the story and understand but not really important if you just want a fun online shooter with some friends. All in all despite its problems i would say its not a bad buy for the price and on sale well worth it and hopefully the developers will keep supporting this game for as long as possible as with good support it could be excellent. PS Peacekeeper signing off..........

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												As a fan of the show, and of MMOs in general. I really wanted to like this game. I was pumped when the whole thing was announced. A sci fi MMO that ties in with a TV show?! Brilliant! What a great idea!  I tried, lord did I try, I even brought a few friends in who didn't last nearly as long as I did.It only shows 0.5 hours played for me, but that's probably cause I uninstalled and reinstalled a couple times. I'v certainly put more than 100 hours into this. Probably closer to 200. I don't have anything to point out that others haven't already. The game is repetitive and lacks anything original. It sucked me in at first, but once the questlines run out, you're basically just driving around the map looking for group events, a lot of the time, by the time you get there the group is finishing up and you missed out on most of the good action. It's really not awful, it's just not a game you're gonna sink 300+ hours into. The reviews say mostly positive, but if you're looking for a game that's gonna hold your attention for a while. This is not it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												I was first bitten by the Free to Play model a few years ago and have not looked back since.  I have tried many games at this point and have seen them run the gambit.  Defiance contains the polish and content that is worth your time.  I played for many hours before opting to reward the developers with some of my cash.  Note is was not necessary for gameplay or needed for progression.  Defiance has an interesting story line that piqued my curiosity enough for me to check out a few episodes of Defiance on Amazon Prime, and plan on continuing to watch.  It is my understanding that there are codes given out at the end of each episode for free in games items.  These rewards are only given out during an active season and as we are in between seasons I am NOT able to verify this but am hopeful.  The game does not really hold your hand and the community is small so expect to have to figure some game play mechanics on your own.  I encountered some minor lag issues and quest bugs but I have not anything that is completely broken.  All in all this is one of the better Free to Play MMO’s out there.  Give it a try I think you will be pleasantly surprised!!

content:
Posted: March 2
												Review by xTzharkz.Short version: - free to play - pay to win - OK storyline - Skill/perk tree - good graphics - good voice acting - good animations - open world  - lots of weapons/vechiles - tons of quests/challenges - PvP possibilitySo yeah the game is OK since it is free to play. I did play it before when it cost like 20 euros. It is fun to play for some time but then it gets sort of boring because most of the stuff is same. Go there shoot done - I guess that is what this game is about but still, every mission like this.I do like the fact that it was possible to do challenges to unlock new looks/vechiles. Combat system was great. Enemies with weakspots so had to think how to defeat them. Also is possible to just duel with others which is fun if other player is at same skill level.Playing with friends is what makes it more fun - can fool around. Otherwize gets boring after a while.Since it is open world there will be many high level players who are very powerful and just killing all the monsters when there are those events. Which made it so lame because going to event with a huge hype and all I could do was watch those huge rocket explodions. Yeah.. was sort of disappointment.Anyway I still recommend to try it out. It is free. xTzharkz [Eric].

												This third person (over the shoulder) shooter is also an MMORPG. It incorporates skill-trees to upgrade your perks and it's incredibly fun using them. Figured I'd write something for this game since there are so few reviews on it. I hope you enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												If you are looking for a resounding "Yea, sire, this is a truly great game of video. Thee shalt pay much of thine coin!" in this review, then you have not played this game. In my experience, it is a great game, with some okay potential, although this has gone downhill fast. with shallow storylines, uninteresting characters, and an underwhelming "Silicon Valley" update (be aware that that was Trion's BIGGEST UPDATE YET), this is not a game to invest money in.ALTHOUGH!The lore and world, combined with plentiful serious moments make up for all of this. It is an open-world MMORPG. You can always skip the main questline and do what you wish. It can be your own story, with a little grinding. Try to make up a story in your head, and ask for RPers in the Chatbox. You won't regret it, and it can be loads of fun.ALTHOUGH! (again)I did not do this. I feel the main storyline is lacking. The only good characters in the beginning easily lose their influence later on. The bad ones, like Cass Ducar, get better toward San Francisco, so just bear in mind that opinion. The show does nothing to complement the story at all. So, I recommend you experience them as seperate franchises.(And the show becomes a bit of a soap opera, so the game is still better.)I believe that Trion has lost it's footing completely. They can only keep this game due to a vast amount of product placement by Dodge. SERIOUSLY, WHY THE HECK IS DODGE SO IMPORTANT IN THIS MULTI-FACTION CRISIS? HECK, EVEN THE "MARK OF THE DEFIANT" IS THE DODGE LOGO!Excuse my rant, but Trion is putting a minimal amount of work into this game. The DLCs are pretty much just a few new vendors. (Excluding Gunslinger Trials, Castithian Charge, and Arkbreaker) You will like it for a while, but I recommend other games for long-term. It functions best as an F2P game.The weapon mechanics can be summed up in one quote. DEATH TO ALL PLAYERS -Trion Worlds. You can shoot an enemy in the face 20 times, leaving him with 60% health. Mind = blown. There are no people who do PvE anymore, so you pretty much solo everything. All the enemies have bulletproof faces, so you have to do them one at a time with five other enemies firing at you. The weapons are all horrible. An assault rifle 4 levels below an LMG still does more damage. The tolerable weapons have little ammo, so you need to constantly reload and backtrack 200m just to grab some ammo. All in all, this game is a great challenge to skilled gamers such as myself and everyone that can stand this game. There are really no reasons to keep playing other than that. I'm moving on to another game.Sincerely,Your Supreme Presidente,Mechawomp

												I don't have many hours, and I'll probably keep playing because the gameplay isn't horrible, but I'm giving it thumbs down for one big reason. A patch released in 2013 that broke the launcher for windows 64bit users is still unfixed in 2016. On the forums the dev's recommend uninstalling a windows security file that the game conflicts with to resolve the issue. Which means they acknowledged the problem and said who cares. The only other way to play the game is to always run it as administrator which bypasses the security issue.In the end the gameplay has me coming back, but I would never spend money on a game when the devs treat the fanbase this way.

												Defiance is definitely an interesting game.  The storyline starts off well, but I felt somewhat cut off from what exactly was going on.  I progressed, I participated in collective, massive battles of 50-100 people, I participated in the instance levels that came with the game.  It is definitely an TPS and it works well for the shooting part.However, if you haven't watched the show this is based upon, then you will definitely lose out.  I have not watched the show, and I barely knew what exactly was going on.  The military was involved somehow, and the sidequests made very little sense.  Some of the missions were super difficult for 1 player in story mode.  And I was armed to the teeth with grenades and assault rifles.  What really ticked me off is that I would kill enemies in my story instance, use up all my grenades doing so, one person survives and kills me off.  What happens?  The story instance restarts with all the enemies coming back alive to full health and ammo.  Except I have no grenades and no ammo.  Every time I had to restart, the story instance would restart and I would not.  This happened many times, and eventually I was spending an hour on a simple mission, because I had to kill every enemy all over with next to no ammo and grenades.The massive battles were interesting, but there were no rewards other than shared xp (amongst a hundred people).  Also turns out I can explore the whole map at any level, and there is literally nothing that interested me landmark wise.  Everything is almost the same everywhere.  The skills were decently thought out, and the skills as well as the lack of lag and graphical distortion were really the only positives for me.Don't get me wrong, if you enjoy TPS and you have a few other friends who like 'em and you wanna just fool around in an MMO with guns, then maybe this could be a game to do so in.  But it loses it's fun very fast.  In my personal opinion, it was not worth the buy.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Smooth and sweet! I have to admit. I was EXCEPTIONALLY skeptical of this game and tried the free trial thinking I would hate it, and end up uninstalling it. I had just uninstalled Neverwinter, a title run by the same company that made another mmorpg. They used allot of elements in their first mmorpg (Star Trek) in Neverwinter and it felt so bad and horribly cloned I could not stand it. In TRION's Defiance, I was very worried I would be playing RIFT like character models. However, it was NOT the case. I was very surprised at how smooth the character was moving around and how engaging the story was. There are cutscenes and an over all story arc that pulls you into the world and makes it feel living.There is an opening cutscene very egaging and interesting to watch. It ties in fluidly to introduce your character and put you right into the mmorpg open world. This is a hard concept most developers CANNOT pull off. If you read my Neverwinter review, you would see how I was so dissapointed that the game has a great system of cinematics mixed with in game gameplay for the first 5 levels, then abruptly cuts off and leaves you with rinse and repeat quest hubs and over all compelling story. In fact, most games are like this. Or you do a bunch of meangless tasks to hit that one point in the game that unlocks a small video file to show you what is going. But it feels awaward at best and interuptive and more of a "reward" for reaching this point in the game.In defiance, this is not the case. The movie starts and then the action and what happens next and how the movie cuts in the game is SUPER fluid with everything you interact with. I was so impressed with how this made up the world that as an FPS and as an MMORPG this out performed almost all games I have been testing over the years. Especially the F2P... I am just blown away at the quality and detail used to create the "I am here, and have a mission, and it is important" feel of the game. The publisher uses NPCs that mix right in with the cinematic scenes. It is very generous to give the story telling in a smooth, interesting, and over all pleasing game play experience.When not doing the main story arc missions, you will run across "side quests" or live events happening all over the living world. You have open world littered with buildings and forest and encampments well entrenched. There is no stretch of land not used to it's potential to create the living world. As you travel you can pick up these side quests and help some fellow troops pinned down in a persistant battle. You can help link up to a computer system or enter a gun fight  to give aid to your fellow man in arms. These are the "visible" side quests on the map. There are allot of activities and war far events that are popping up off the radar that make you stop pathing to your quest and end up fully engaged in an entire other aspect of the game. I often found myself heading to my quest objective marked on the map, only to run across my people pinned down by gun fire asking for help. As soon as I enter the live zone the objectives are displayed...perhaps other players are already inside progressing and I am much needed back up as an extra gun...You see, that is GREAT co-op mmorpg features that bring people together! A live, persistent world always doing things that, if done together (or solo) will reward and not feel meaningless.As an MMORPG this game shines! It also has arc falls that bring people together for mini raid battles. EXACTLY like in RIFT. This is a meteor like thing that drops from the sky and you have to kill off the enemies waves, and then strategically shoot at weak points in the crystal. The more people doing it the better and it was not surprising to get into a group of 20 easy. There are several mission types and enough things to do to keep replay ability at a high.I did say "a meteor like thing" because I have no idea what the TV show has explained about these. As a player who never watches the series I was a little lost in the dialog at times. They talk about how it is bad these aliens are doing things or this technology does this or that...I was totally lost. But it is clear that you are human. Earth was attacked. Technology was to blame. And it is now your mission to help the resistant movement or something rather. So the story is given out on a need to know easy to take in basis. And honestly, I like it! It is interesting, engaging, and works perfectly to get us moving along the path. No "You are hero fighting for wealth and kingdom" bull crap. A real cinematic and game play experience to push this fantasy world forward. If I had on negative point, it is that in character creation, you have a choice of voice for your avatar, yet he rests silent in the cut scenes. It also is not DEEP as other mmorpgs as far as crafting and getting lost in menus and micro managing your stats all over the place. But it gives you just enough to be deep and thought out.The skill system for example. YOu pick what kind of soldier you want to be and form this out through skills. You start on a grid and start with a choice of 4 points to start branching out in. Stealth, speed, damage, defense skills etc... I chose a cloak that makes me hide from enemiesrefills my shield for about 5 seconds. After I chose this base skill, all the other skills around it unlocked and I Start building out. I can give bonus to critic damage by crouching. OR chose bonus dmg to enemies rushing you...So you start to see, if you are a fighter that likes to hang back and crouch behind a object, you can build this kind of character to suit your game play.If you like to snipe, you can get scopped bonuses. If you like to rush it you can get bonuses to that. The developers logically and awesomely built the skills and game around letting you fight how you want. I have tried so many FPS and you have to do one thing or the other, and in general all game play is the same. In this, you are complimented to play at your rhythm, style, and nature.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												This game looks decent enough to try but after spending a couple days playing it, it no longer is a decent game but a terrible game. The game has been out for over a year according to wiki but this game has tons of bugs with 4 DLC with a 5th suppose to be released.The game mechanics are broken in that since you're actually required to shoot the mobs, the mobs love to teleport due to glitches. Kinda hard to hit mobs when they teleport around. You carry limited ammo and if you choose sniping, you will quickly find yourself out of ammo or praying that you take down the mob in 4-5 head shots(not kidding about the amount of headshots). Instances are not bound by walls so if you were to get knocked over anytype of short barriers and into the water, you will die or spend 10 minutes getting back into the area if you are able to get up the shore.The community is worse in that nobody really communicates in this game other than if you are in a clan. You are limited to only type in chat when you are at the main play screen, not the loadout menu or any other menu. You can't skip cutsceens and will repeat cutsceeens regardless of the amount of times you are redoing an instance. There is no actual player class. That is the only good thing going for this game except good luck getting a great weapon for the style you want to play. Some of the other weapons are broken and will not even damage mobs on explosion.

												This game showed a lot of promise originally and reminded me of an open-world Phantasy Star Online so I was riding on a nostalgia high horse when I started playing Defiance. I liked the story missions and even went out of the way to do all the side missions. I liked the lack of the MMO Trinity in dungeons and the PvP was refreshing with a choice of instanced or open world.I bought the game for several friends in fact and we all enjoyed it together.2-3 weeks later you've pretty much done everything the game has to offer a few times and up to a dozen times and more of other certain aspects and all the magic is gone. The show is suppose to time in to the game and vice versa but that's all but vanished and died.They did add some melee weapons as well so updates are still happening but at an incredibly slow rate (maybe 1-2 a year given current track record) and none of these really add any content for the endgame.If you're looking for something to last you the weekend than by all means get the game, it'll occupy your time nicely.But, if you're expecting something you can keep coming back to? Look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2013
DefianceI really like playing this game! Defiance is now a free to play game so no investment other than your time is needed to play and enjoy this game.  I initially purchased Defiance while looking for something new to play with my family.  I did not have any expectations for this game and had never seen the Scify TV series, but I was surprised to see that even my wife liked it and she normally will not play a shooter, even if it is an MMORPG.Game DesignDefiance has a lot of good design features with it like dungeon/pvp grouping tools as well as a limitless questing network.  The game uses a feature for looting similar to Rift, also a TRION Worlds game, in that you do not have to be grouped to receive loot from a kill.  The game uses Rift's rift (outdoor raid) feature but calls them ark falls.  The game also uses a system that allows players to play with others at any level and still receive xp and loot.  This is a double side coin that can make game play feel very repetitive.  The leveling prgress in the game are not your typical 1-50 levels.  In defiance you level to 5000, although I do not believe it takes any longer than the more traditional level design of 1-50.  With your levels you get points to develope your character's talents/trates/perks. Unlike other MMORPGs, Definace does little to specialize classes/races.  Other than the Castithan race which gets to use a dagger/sword melee weapon, there is nothing special about picking the race or class at the beginning of the game.  StoryDefiance's lore runs hand in hand with the popular TV series on the Syfy network.  The game and TV show writters/developers work with each other to make sure what one does, the other does as well. They even went as far a putting in a gamer's character into the show after holding a contest to pick the lucky gamer.  The GoodI really like the control and gameplay.  The loots system is great.  When doing an event or quest the item rewards are based on your level, not the zone.  The grouping system works very well for PvE and PvP.  The game is interwoven with the TV series. The BadGraphically, the character models could look better.  The game engine is last gen.  Because the NPCs adjust to the level appropriate for the gamer so to speak, the game feels repetitive even when completing new quests. And last, there is no class specialization or specialized class missions so there is no value in leveling more than one character which limits replay value.ConclusionDo I recommend it?  Absolutely!  It is a fun game that is now free to play so you have nothing to lose but the time investment of trying something new. 


YouTube™ Video: Defiance for new players: On AbandonWare

			Here is my 2016 review for players who may be thinking about trying out Defiance on PC. This is my opinion on Trion games MMO Defiance, the game that was tied to the TV Show Defiance on SyFy.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												This is a gamepad-friendly third-person shooter, that takes a lot of influence from games like Borderlands. Enemies tend to be bullet-spongy in this open-world RPG. You'll have access to your own vehicle after a short while, and you can purchase more than one.  Your character's armor and weapons can be modded by buying parts with money you made from selling loot, or by stripping parts off of the weapons of fallen enemies.  Weapons vary all the way from healing tools to multi-grenade-lobbing doomsday devices.  You'll always be on the lookout for better stats.  This is the functional predecessor to games like The Division, but you will run into players everywhere, and random group instances are aplenty. You don't necessarily need to roll with anyone else. You will bump into other people, and you're on the same side, so the tendency is to help one another. You don't make dialog choices, and some quests are text-based, but the game really feels alive, despite the fact that the story NPCs kinda always just sit in the same spot. This game has so much amazing free content, I bought a $5 hat for my character from the cash shop just to support the developers. The cash shop sells nothing but vanity items and minor boosters. The boosters will not necessarily make you better than your friends, you'll just gain a little more XP for an hour or something like that.  There is honestly so little reason to spend money, the game is so full already, I honestly don't know how their business model works. This is one of the best F2P TPS MMORPGs out there. It's free, so if you think I'm wrong, who cares? Try it!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Its an ok shooter. BUT; considering the sheer number of micro transations in it; it leaves A LOT to answer for.  Its fun; but its far to repetative. It relies too much on transations; I actually reccomended an award for it "Most Micro Transations in a Free-To-Play".  I've played my fair share of them; while Combat Arms holds a VERY close 2nd in this catagory at the very least CA comes through with above average connectivity; and well better graphics.  For the staggering $$$ that is being thrown at this game it should have by this phase of its life had several graphics upgrades as well as monster additions and less leaning on the micro transactions.  I can get behind a free to play that has a pay wall or two (fashion and some extra inventory space/faster and slightly better pay for weapons) but this heaping pile of trash can't really even boast that.  Sure you pay around $20.00 for the "gold pack" but if you look at the higher tier packs you really get next to nothing for the Breath taking $150.00+ for advancing packs..... Having payed into Skyrim about that for all 3 DLC (and the accompaning hard drive to fit the ever expanding eye candy mods) I can say this game has NO excuse for the Garbage Truck Sized Turd it jams into your eye... it is reminiss of the scene from TWD when Negan was talking to Rick and had just carted away all their matresses... yup.. just.. like.. that.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												Okay I put quite a bit of time into the retail version of this game. It is a 3rd Person MMORPG which ties into the tv show of the same name. I enjoy it as it has an open world to explore, story missions, episode missions, arkfall events, competitive and co-op modes. The weapons are quite varied but they don't scale with level, although rarity can make a big difference, You pick an ego power but basically level up various perks. So a low level can balance against a high level. I find it fun and it reminds me a bit of Warhammer online, which was another under-rated game. Also you don't have to play it constantly to get the most out of it, but can just jump in for quick games.

content:
Posted: January 16
												A game I first played on the PS3, this game is basically a third-person Borderlands. In this game, you help your boss, Mr. Von Bach use ark-tech to do whatever crazy stuff he wants to do. The ark-tech was the thing that destroyed the world in the first place.One thing to note: Rocket Launchers get 50 rounds. That is extremely overpowered. Especially when you don't need to buy ammo, you get it for free. This is an extremely fun free open world MMO shooter. The only problem that it repeatedly has is the server. Friends will often lag slightly when driving places. Or the server just won't work at all. Arkfalls are the easiest ways to get Scrip (in-game currency), weapons, and experience to level up your EGO level. I recommend doing those when you get the chance. Even appearing last-minute gives you rewards.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
												TLDR: Defiance is a few mechanics short of being an awesome game. But, still very recommended.PROS1. It's one of the few Shooter MMORPG that's a legit questing experience, rather than a survival game.2. The controls are pretty smooth (not Warframe smooth, but maybe CoD smooth)3. Nice graphics4. Open World with almost no invisible walls.5. Similar to WIldstar, their F2P version is the base game and subscribing gives you extra rewards, instead of making you OP.6. Various ways to level: Standard Quests, Timed Quests, Arkfalls (random events), Battlegrounds, etc...7. Nice selection of weapons.8. Although there's no real difference between any of the races or classes (aside from looks), your skills and abilities (like talents) and choice of weapons and playstyle is what makes you unique. 9. You can stealth, go berzerk, throw out decoys or become a blur.10. It's an actual PvE centered MMO shooter! CONS1. Bots2. The AI in the game is kind of stupid...Fallout 4 has a pretty good AI, where you can hide in shadows, sneak, and mob have a field of vision in which they can detect you. In Defiance all of the mobs pathing is the same so if you run around a corner and stay against a the wall, you can gun the NPCs down one at a tipe, as they run at you in a single file line.3. P2W, you can buy currency that buys better gear, and you can buy better gear with real money.4. Vehicle is fun to use but has a slight learning curve.5. Chat is isolated in the bottom right, so unless you're on voice coms, or constantly looking at the chat bar (only shows one line of chat at a time, when minimized), it almost feels like a single player game, with other players running around.6. Character creation is very limitted.7. No real difference between the 'class' or 'race' you pick.All in all, this game is fun, and in some situations it's flaws is what makes it entertaining. It's definitely worth trying out, but be warned, it is a pay to win game (if you want to PvP).

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Defiance is a Third Person Shooter action game with MMO elements. It features some fairly well done combat mechanics (namely, moving and shooting is pretty robust) and a full campaign. I've probably burned around 85 hours on it by now, and have a pretty high level character.That being said, Defiance has a lot of problems that I can elaborate on.1. Combat: The game can go from laughably easy to incredibly hard based on the drop of a hat. Wide, open free roaming environments can lead to long range combat to reach an objective, but then upon reaching the objective enemies spawn in point blank.  The shooting elements handle well, the enemy types can be fairly diverse, but with the exception of the very powerful Volge enemy types (think, large metal roboguys who can almost 4 shot you near the beginning of the game) enemies are kind of weak unless in very large numbers. The AI has some predetermined behaviors that are easy to learn and counter for, and occasionally you'll have a lot of fun fighting off multiple enemies at a time. However, the difficulty scales very inconsistently, often going from cakewalk to instant death depending on the location and mission.2. Single Player Elements: Campaign missions are not consistent in their difficulty nor are they especially interesting after having done one of the four possible types of mission. These types essentially are "Go here and push a button, kill the guys, repeat", "Go here and shoot some guys, grab a thing and come back", "Go here and do this repeatable quest" and "Go here and do a minidungeon". The single player parts also offer a plot involving an "Ark Core" or whatever said plot-driver is and a few characters who are generic and underbuilt. Final boss is a refreshing dose of difficulty, but is both too little and too late to make a huge impact.3. Multiplayer Elements: Coop and Competitive multiplay exist in Defiance. Coop modes have Dungeons and more Organic repeatable missions that reset periodically in the world. That being said, Coop tends to be incredibly easy for essentially the vast majority of the game's possible playable parts- save for one AND ONLY ONE segment- the Major Ark Fall that is called down by players buying a purchasable item through the Defiance store. This Major Ark Fall event features significant quantities of per-player scaling robobaddies ready to screw you up. That being said, the Major Ark Fall calldown is only difficult for its final boss, which is something of a behemoth of incredibly frustrating AoE attacks and is basically unkillable for the most part (unless, say, an entire clan of orginized players goes after it with a very specific technique). Competitive multiplay is by queued instance only, it seems, although there is a "Shadow War" pvp event which I have never seen in action. Multiplayer has some balance issues due to the weapon generation systems, currently (01.11.2014) there is a sniper rifle that can charge up its shot, and break appart the shot into individual shots (making a sniper with a tight shotgun like spread). This "Surge Bolter" style of rifle is incredibly overpowered at this point, due to a balance patch that made all Semi-Automatic rifles do more damage than previously. I figure this weapon is probably bad for multiplayer just because it can 1 or 2 shot people really frequently and has no accuracy modifier caused by movement/standing/jumping.4. Logistics: The menus are awful, but navigatable if you learn how they work like I did. That being said, they desperately need some serious revisions especially in the Item Comparison department (which is currently, essentially broken). The modification section of the menus, known as the "Salvage Forge" is used to modify weaponry to make them have extra magazine size, a scope, ect, as well as to reset the "Weapon Mastry" points on a weapon, to make it able to level up player weapon skill despite having been used a lot by the player. The player to player interactions are also somewhat flawed, the "Quick Menu" features multiple types of functions that CANNOT BE ACCESSED ANYWHERE ELSE. This basically means that the radial escape menu and the various player menus regarding character are all disconnected from Adding friends, joining a clan, ect.5. Overall Opinion: Say, a 1 point game is something like Full Spectrum Warrior (an unworkable piece of garbage), a 5 is say Dead Space 2 (Working, but lacking significantly in some serious aspects regarding player experience) and a 10 is closer to Half Life 2 (arguably one of the best experiences gameplay wise in my opinion); Defiance is a whimpy 4/10 because of many reasons stated above, and some others I haven't gotten to. I really, really love third person shooter games, and this one in particular captured my attention with the decent combat mechanics and the layers of possible depth (unlockables, however, are all that are left by this point), but lost me because of failure to carry through an enjoyable experience. I still had fun with this game, but often only because of shooting a badguy in some kind of impressive way (see: 360 no scope with that overpowered sniper rifle I talked about), or laughing at my friends when we could make the game's party functions work for us. If it goes on sale for 5 bucks, I recommend trying it out if you're really into the Borderlands style of game (respawns, MMO format, active weapon play, decent combat mechanics) but I strongly suggest bringing some FRIENDS or you will probably never be able to justify the ~18gb of this games overall size.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												I will let it be known i've bought this a few years since its launch so its not as bad for me as say people who had it  at launch but this game still has many flaws within its system and thats not even adding UI eyesores like the chat. But what this game has going for it is a constant stream of activity even if there are times where you wont see another player for a good 4-5 mins depending on the time of day. I'd really say this is a heavily unfinished product, i dare even say its a tv/movie license game at its worst and even the developers see that now that they have set it down to 9.99. Trion whatever the hell you were thinking it may have just screwed you because now as is this is barely even worth the 9.99 you brought it down too and i hope for both our sakes the gaming community learns from this. With that said if you are willing to buy it i assure you will at least get some fun out of it but definitely nowhere near what everyone was expecting before its release.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is great! Bought it during the sale for just $4.99, more than worth it. I haven't tried the DLCs yet though, but the base game itself is epic. There are lots of players in this game, it's really an MMO (for now), the graphics are nice, loot is very cool, tons of guns to use ingame. My favourite part is when dozens of players gather at the same times to participate in an Arkfall. It's really cool. There are also PvP / Co-op missions where players will have to queue for. I reccomend this game, it's really worth $4.99. ~79/100.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Defiance was big on potential but short on execution. Trion obviously cut corners under pressure to meet the deadline, however issues existing since launch (such as a broken chat system, and glitchy and jarring audio dialogue including from the overtalkative and much-despised "sidekick" named EGO) have been repeatedly put off as a priority in favor of new items for microtransactions. During the last show season, the new "weekly content" mostly turned out to be audio recorders that players had to hunt for - "live events" such as the plague infestation were few and far between, which was a solid negative mark for a game premised on fluid interaction with the TV show. The fact that Defiance dropped from $60 to $10 in less than a year should be a red flag to anyone contemplating buying it.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												I bought this game when it was $15, logged all the hours I have listed and then uninstalled it. I've taken a look at the game since it went F2P and I'm not impressed.First, all the content initially promised is still lacking; We were told that there would be 6 playable races, we have 3 (with the 3rd still requiring you to buy the Casti pack if you want to select it). The DLCs we were teased with in order to get us to buy the season pass do not exsist. What we got were crappy, half-♥♥♥♥♥ minor add-ons that aren't worth $10 and add little to the game. Aside from Arkbreaker, the one DLC to be worth paying $10 for, the rest only provide you with reskined weapons, new costumes (that odds are you won't want) and some diversions that don't last long for most people. And the type of content you'd expect to have been free (new co-op maps, weapon and mods, reputation missions, etc) are all effectivly behind DLC paywalls, even now.On top of that, your character has little to no personality. You literilly don't speak a word, even when you'd expect your character, who is supposed to be this uber-badass, would actually speak up. Instead you get a "voice" that you can change at will, which is really just a bunch of random crap that your character will spit out in combat or when you get in a vehicle. The rest of the time, you'll hear EGO, who sounds like the annoying evolution of the "Hey, Listen!" fairy from Zelda on the N64.EGO powers are bland and often make little difference in most fights, including bosses. Weapon stats are the same, and all higher rarity weapons give you are more pre-opened mod slots and bonus abilities on the weapon. After a while the game becomes an near endless grind to get all your weapon levels to 20 and your EGO to 5,000. At 200+ hours in and having finished the game (save for the last boss, because ♥♥♥♥ a solo only boss fight with 3 phases, one hit kills and no chance to replenisn ammo or HP between phases), my character is only at 1,700 or so and I've only gotten 2 weapon levels to the max, so you do the math on how long it's take to do it all.As a F2P, you're welcome to give this game a go. But honesly, even now I don't see it as worth it. Unless Trion drops a massive series of tweaks and updates, the game is effectivly just as bad (if not worse) than when I stopped playing.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Defiance isn't really a bad game. In fact, now that it's free to play, it's worth spending a weekend in. The hybrid skill system allows for a diversity of play styles that its direct counterpart Borderlands lacks, first of all-- the prevalence of the "Re-Spec" button and its relative cheapness means that it's worth experiencing the game from all four skills. The game has lots of spontaneous quests that can give more meaning to the world than going from point A to point B.As far as gameplay, it's basically Borderlands trying to take itself seriously. That means a couple things: more serious story, for one, which isn't necessarily bad, but is really quite average. The guns are more bland as well, to fit the 'seriousness', which in turn makes gameplay more, well, average. Defiance is a game that suffers not from any fatal flaws but from being only okay at everything it does. It gets dull because there are no highs and lows, only flat lines.This is a great game to spend some ten hours on, sure, but after that progression becomes so slow and encounters so repetitive that it's better to simply uninstall.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												This game is average. It's more of a co-op multiplayer shooter than an MMOFPS. If you wanted MMO features, I can only tell you that these are in small numbers and pretty much bare bones. If you wanted your classic MMO just with shooter features, you will be sorely disappointed.The "quests" aren't taken from NPCs in towns (there aren't even any towns, just some peaceful areas amongst the battlefield that is the rest of the map) but they are spread across the map and they're always about activating some things or killing enemies or both. Thing is these quests become very quickly very repetitive and boring. Also, you can do the same quest multiple times as enemies will respawn rather fast after you completed it (which, imo, is very lame and breaking the immersion). The game is FILLED with visual glitches, such as players disappearing from in front of you and reappearing, which looks quite bad when you got a lot of players blinking as you approach them.This game is pretty mediocre for our time. I'd say it's actually a more complex Global Agenda than an MMO.

The PVP is alright, it wasn't special, if you've played some of the other PVP modes in games like Tomb Raider and (insert another generic triple A here) you'll know what to expect.All in all it's a typical F2P with a tonne of microtransactions, if you want to change your look it's gonna cost you, if you want a different coloured quad bike it'll cost you some of that moolah.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												I really don't understand all the negative reviews. I think this is a great game, I enjoy it very much. Easy to start, you can play only 20 minutes if you like. And it's free, you know. You really can easily put 100 hours in and still enjoy it, for FREE. I bought the season pass anyways, it's just costs as much as a normal game would.I like that there are short and long mission, big events with about a hundred players, you can hop in for only a few minutes or take part in hour long events.I've played about 140 hours now and haven't ever felt that I need to put real money in the game. I bought the season pass DLCs only out of respect for the developers, and still didn't finish all the mission in them.Locations and events are kind of repetitive and reused a lot, but every now and then I change my gear and gameplay changes a lot with a new type of gun.So, I think the game is worth trying and putting in the first 5-10 hours of getting the feel of the game. Anyways, the best part starts when you get to the second big location, to your 3rd fast travel point.

number of helpful: 18 of 34 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This is probably the best shooter MMO out there.  The community is actually nice (when they can type!) and people listen and respond.  The action is crazy fun, the vehicles are fun to drive too.. getting air off a big hill is awesome.  And the weapons.. so many different types and all with their own upgradable parts that each of their own stats.It's definitely worth a try (It's free to play, so.. why not?).EDIT:  Just to add a few things:  The show crossover is getting really interesting.  You don't have to know anything about the show to be able to play the game, but it's pretty cool to recognize the races and some of the people in the game as also being in the TV Show.I have to say also, after playing Firefall for awhile.. Defiance is truly a superior game in every regard.  The only thing you can do in Firefall that you can't do in Defiance is fly.. if you put points in the right area.  And all that gets you is a few less hits from melee mobs and a whole lot more hits from ranged.There really is no better shooter MMO out there.  And with all the new content they add pretty much weekly, Defiance is growing and changing all the time.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												If you stick to F2P in this game it isn't bad as far as I can tell. However if you want to pay their packages are a bit absurd. For instance you can buy all dlc content for 60 dollars and that isn't all that bad. However they have special sets of armor that can cost upwards of 145 dollars, yes you get some in game currency. Although if I am paying 150 dollars for a game then I expect that to also cover the cost of all the dlc's and more. On top of that if you go with a monthly plan that is another 6 to 12 dollars a month depending on which plan you get. To top it off there will always be more packages to buy so a month down the line the new set of armor may be another 145. If you compare this to the pricing of something like WoW where it is 20 for a combined package of all previous WoW items and then 60 to 70 for the new expansion and then something like 6 to 12 a month and thats it then the pricing in Defiance is just absurd. It's a shame too because it really has the MMO Borderlands feel to it.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												Defiance... If you enjoy an open world, free roam, multi-mission, mmo, rpg style, guns, pvp, coop, welllllll daaang! The list will keep on going. To me this game is like Firefall/Warframe. A mix of Borderlands classic looks for vehicles, armors, and weapons. Ark Falls as you level up prove more challenging and drop goods from beginning to the end of every battle. The game seems to go with your pace of leveling. So however you play in any game, will reflect on how quickly you level, gain awesome mods, weapons and more. Along with areas showing more side missions than you know what to do with. Group up with 1 to many people or run like a lone wolf. You like racing? Alone? This game has it... putting you up against the world of players on the leaderboards. PVP your style? Defiance has got it! Mind you this game has its bugs, quirks and lag points. Like with any game you find yourself immerced in an open world of gliches and lag spikes along with a rich world of never ending adventures! So with that, hope to see y'all on the battlefields of Defiance! ~D (Admiral Hawke - Defiance)(Now, NSI-DiabolicaHawke, Founder of NSI Nothing Stops Insanity)

With its lack of any subscription fees makes it all the more enjoyable. All-In-All it's better than wow, nuff said.

												This game is amazing. There is a huge post apocalyptic world out there for you to explore and it really looks alive. There are players which who you can team up and NPCs aren't just some random characters that give you pointless quests, they really look alive.I'e been travelling the map for days with nothing but my bike and just exploring. If you want to experience this game properly don't use fast travel. The action is dynamic and full of adreanaline, so get ready to be on the losing team until you get the hang of things. Some people have been complaining that it is a pay to win, but it simply isn't true. Paying can speed things up, but if you solve quests and explore the world arround you there is no stoping you!Download and play it, you wont regret it.

												A pretty good F2P MMOTPS. Kind of underrated and undervalued. Good designs, Inferior Graphtech, but graphically superior in terms of visual appeal/artstyle. (To understand what I mean by this: I feel DOOM 1993 is graphically superior to most AAA titles of today, as do I feel the same of STRAFE. However, their graphics tech is not as good as the given titles of today.- suffice to say, I value a good artstyle more than I do the graphics.)Fairly unique in it's intended approach to have a show that effects the game, and vice-versa. There's also hidden stuff all over the place. Go explore.Be on the lookout for any codes.

												Over all fun game. Lots of weapons to chose from which all have their own personality. The vehicles are fun to ride around in, as well.  It isn't horrible like most people say, there is a lot to do in the game and I rarely get bored even when I am playing by myself.  I highly recommend this for anyone looking for an adventure/first-person shooter to play with your friends.  The global events allow for everyone to join in on the excitement and you can help others with their missions as well, without having to be teamed.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												This game is amazing. There is a huge post apocalyptic world out there for you to explore and it really looks alive. There are players which who you can team up and NPCs aren't just some random characters that give you pointless quests, they really look alive.I'e been travelling the map for days with nothing but my bike and just exploring. If you want to experience this game properly don't use fast travel. The action is dynamic and full of adreanaline, so get ready to be on the losing team until you get the hang of things. Some people have been complaining that it is a pay to win, but it simply isn't true. Paying can speed things up, but if you solve quests and explore the world arround you there is no stoping you!Download and play it, you wont regret it.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												It's OK. I dont like the fact you have to buy the game and there is still a micro transaction store. Games that do greedy stunts like this usually fail and this game is no exception. The only cash shop items that matter are the item boxes and those can be obtained in game. So it is not P2W but is highly pay to accelerate. Most of your customization also comes from the cash shops.Aside from that its not bad the guns are fun to shoot and there is alot of variety. The mmo aspects seem to be lacking, but you can join in on a mission in progress as they are not instanced. I have not played long enough to comment on the end game content.It is also very repetitive. Seven hours in and can already feel the grind. There is hardly any variety in the mutants you have to kill in this game and it gets very bland and boring quick.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												Have you ever played a kind of bad game then still play it for some reason? This is one of those games.This MMO is set in the future. Humanity was forced to have literal illegal aliens migrate to their planet and technology greatly prospered. But however, there is one faction that is like so damn xenophobic. It is the Dark Matter. Dark Matter are these cool looking space xenophobes who make up the alien races that came from the collection of illegals. Honestly, I think my favorite MMO villains are the Dark Matter. Plus, they have giant robots. Pros:PvP is easy as hell. Just get a radioactive SMG and a grenade launcher. I once got this amazing score by blowing up almost the entire enemy force. They all cloaked and for some reason decided to go in this corridor where I was. I had the sneaking suspicion that I was being looked at so I fired a couple of grenades and detonated them. Got a couple of kills so I proceeded to then just blow the HELL out of that corridor and got more kills. Explosion simulator 10/10The enemies are pretty cool. First we have cybernetic miners who for some reason are very hostile. Next we have mutants. The mutants are a huge threat. They seek to invade D6 like their communist brethern. Woops, wrong game but still...they're pretty much a threat. And finally, we have these giant space armored guys who for some reason remind me of something that I can't even think about. Oh, right! They remind me of the Combine Empire. We also have these space robots who basically robotify you from inside-out. Scary as hell.Cons:The Loot System has some problems. For some odd reason the game reminds us of Borderlands yet there isn't any notice-able gun variety. The quests are very dull at a certain point. Reputations are easy/hard to acquire for some reason to me.My 100% organically grown oranges disapprove of the cons. Ergo, it is a con.The Final Verdict:This game has that weird attraction. It most likely will attract you back if you think about it. Anyways, this game is recommended if you just want to have fun. Believe me if you will, this game is as easy as cooking Meth in PAYDAY 2.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Defiance, here are my thoughts on this Massivelly multiplayer bro shooter. Defiance was a licensed collaboration between Trion World and  the SyFy chanel. Becuase of that fact this game was well funded, but i also think this game may have held back by it's telivision roots. In television ideals and designes have to work within budget, anything to expensive to recreate on television ends up on the cutting room floor. Fast forward to 2015 when the show was cancelled, now the team at Trion Worlds can do what ever they want, so what have they done?Here is my opinion!


YouTube™ Video: Defiance - Gameplay 1 

			Views: 2,657		



In Short Pro's1 Decent story and PVE2 Fun Balls to the walls Shooter3 A lot of content for new gamers4 A fun but small community of good gamers5 Trion Worlds always has events to hold you over between seasons6 Gamepad FriendlyCon's1 This game needs a high resolution Textures and lighting Pack2 Very few options to Adjust visuals 3 Not a lot of new content comes out between seasons

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Defiance is labeled as an Action, Massively Multiplayer, RPG game.  Although it's a MMO without the usual MMO game subscription, the 3rd person combat action mechanic is comparable to pure 3rd person shooter games out there today such as Ghost Recon Future Soldier and Dead Space III.  On the RPG side, it's a bit reminiscent of Borderlands I-II, Dead Island and of course Dead Rising II OTR in terms of the questing, collecting items and... content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												This game was worth paying for as it was, along with all the DLC. It is even more fun when you have a group of friends to play it with, and what better timing, it's no2 a F2P, so get all your friends to get it, and go out with those friends in search for trouble!In my opinion the best DLC I got for this had to be the Castithan Charge Pack DLC. I personally love the element of having some swords in the game, and coloured ones too :DIt had a bad launch, hence the meta score, however all of this has now been fixed, I haven't found a single bug on PC or Console version of Defiance since its release! But hey, it's now free so why would it really matter anyway?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												The gameplay is okay, if you're willing to shell out the money for every expansion. Be aware it's pay2win. PvP is impossible to contest unless you drop $100+. PvE is where the game focuses on. But again there will be a lot of loot you're unable to use without the expansions.The absolute most annoying thing is the newest update. There is an item in game called a cyber rig. It allows you to enhance your style of gameplay. The issue is unless if you're willing to pay the company money, you will not be able to get this item except for 3 times a week. Even if you're successful on the missions, its still only a chance. If you fall in battle it cost another token to continue. Horrible way to make the cyber rig in the game and giving yet another way for pay2win players an advantage in PvP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I've only played Defiance for about an hour now, but I'm already well into downloading this game patch, and I feel I know the game well enough to write up a review.Defiance is a neat data entry simulator where you go to http://orcz.com/Defiance:_Arkfall_Codes and enter 120 of those codes into the Defiance website. Once you've done that, you've won the game! :DYou can continue patching after you've beaten the game. I guess that's like new game plus or something. Right now I'm making a neat Minecraft village while the patch continues. You should see it; it's pretty cool.In conclusion, I would recommend Minecraft for anyone looking to make tiny forts while stuff downloads. :3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Defiance. Have you watched the TV series? Cool, you'll probably be one of the people who understands why that's the name of this game, because there are suprisingly few allusions to it in the game of the same name. That's fine with me, but if I hadn't have watched the show I guess I'd still be wondering if it was one of those gritty, angst-ridden titles that never really lives up to what the Dev's have delivered. Don't get me wrong, I have really enjoyed the time I've put into Defiance so far, and will continue to put in because I am keen to see how it all plays out, but this is a game that definitely has it's great points and also areas where it deserves more work.I have a realtively shallow background when it comes to MMO's, so I was pleasantly surprised to find one that for the most part felt like a single-player with other people running around going about thier daily lives. Being free-to-play is what drew me in in the first place, as I'm currently fascinated with what kind of stuff people consider to be worth absolutely nothing at all (a strange concept considering the amount of work that goes into making a game), and quickly fell victim to the (obviously successful) not-so-micro puchase system. I blame one of my mates who I convinced to play with me, as I probably wouldn't have bouth the DLC if he didn't, thinking that maybe it would have unlocked other territories or given me extra loot capacity, and I was very dissapointed when that was not the case for $20 (AT HALF PRICE!) worth of investation. Yeah I got extra missions and daily currency, but it basically amounted to sweet-♥♥♥♥-all in the grand scheme of things.On the upside though, cutscenes in one-off co-op missions is very enjoyable, especially when they are often funny (in a Borderlandsish way), and they don't seem out of place with the main missions so you start getting a real feel for the characters. In short, Defiance is worth the 14GB download just to play the series missions if nothing else, but I doubt you'll be able to help yourself from getting out and about if you go in with that intent...Key bindings were pretty easy to configure to suit my usual play style, although I'm yet to find a better place than Alt for dodge because I'm not used to being spoiled for choice, having both dodge AND jump. I haven't really played around with in-game voice, but Raidcall seems to be the common theme amongst the clan I hooked up with. That's also something worth a mention - there are good bonuses to being in a clan and having friends. Being able to teleport to them any time you like is the one I have used the most, but you can also recieve boons just from being in a clan. I found this to be a novel concept, and the navigation thing helps get bulk numbers fast for the good instances.There's probably heaps more I could waffle on about, but the main things are that it's a 3rd person shooter with a pretty straightforward RPG system (the most intense decision you'll have to make is what outfit shows of your characters boobs the best), basically troll-proof, and it's free. Why not eh?

Posted: January 21
												Ignore all the people complaining about DLC or being a crap game etc. The game all in all can be harshly argued its pay to win due to some things not being available without paid dlc but in most cases you can work around that fairly easily if you put in the time. The game as a whole is great, little buggy and laggy from the massive amount of people in one place but it's tolerable. There's tons to do and a ton of diversity as far as weapons and (sorta) mobs. Thing is though the game gets stale STUPIDLY fast especially if you're alone. There's random world events and dungeon things you can do but you'll quickly go through hundreds of them within your first few hours of playing and you'll think "Hm, wonder if there's anything new" and then you'll realize no, there isn't. I played on XBOX first and the game was great but again, I found myself running around with no real goal in mind and couldn't get back into it

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												I'm gonna go with a pros and cons type review so here it ispros:-There is a variety of missions, side missions, races and rampages-Many guns(YES)-Vehicles and if you are too lazy, quick transports -Nice (but not too detailed) character creation (not the best but still nice)-You actually need to level different kinda weapons to level up so you get to experience different combat styles -You can choose between various voices for your character-Team work isn't necessary unless you need to do co-op maps-PvP is challenging(which is a necessity)-Missions to level up make you experience different sides of the gameCons:-Help desk isn't very useful (it hasn't been for me at least)-Team work can suck because of certain player types-You can pay to be superior to other players-The game starts to repeat itself after a while especially once you have done the main missions-BuggySo all in all, you can enjoy yourself playing the game but get ready for the rocky parts of the road.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Played it for a while. It's a pretty good game altogether, but not my taste. I prefer shooters where cover and headshots really impact the game, but this game does neither. Sure, headshots give double damage, but the enemy still needs 30 shots to go down. I can see how many people would like this game, but I personally don't. I'm giving it a positive review because I think it's very solid, good lore, good enemies, nice variety of weapons, impressive online experience (playing with others actually increases enjoyability, which is rare in mmo shooters nowadays), massive world to explore and a pleasing visual art style. I dislike it personally due to a lack of direction at the beginning, as I came for a mount promotion from another game, and I dislike how the interactions with npc work (stale animations, almost no cutscenes, straightup lame characters at times) and having a hard time to find places for me to level have made this game a bit cringy to me. I advice you to play it nontheless, because I think people could enjoy this enough to sink a quick 300 hours into it.

												To be honest overall, this isn't really a bad game in general, though it should still be noted that this WAS a retail game gone to a free-to-play format now but don't let that alarm you, as for me at least the whole "pay to win" concept doesn't exist in this game, unless you count that for looking for flashy and in style from the game itself.However the only main issue I'm really getting from this game overall is some lag issues here and there forcing me to miss most of my shots when they should have been registered client-side as the game seems to think I'm just standing still server-side when I'm actually moving, aiming, and shooting client-side.Besides that and whatnot it wouldn't be a terrible idea to try this game out, however I would at least get far and play the game long enough to understand at least SOME concepts of it before considering on purchasing some of the content this game has to offer such as the season pass, but I still have much to look into the other purchasable content other than simple cosmetics.So yeah no I wouldn't deem this a terrible game just because of some of the lag issues and it's a "bullet-sponge", honestly anyone who's complaining about a game being a "bullet-sponge" more than likely only has the poor tastes along the generic lines of battlefield and/or CoD which still just essentially and sadly reskin, remodel, and reuse the same things under a new cover.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that Defiance gets more of a bad wrap than it deserves. Let me just get the negatives out of the way first. It's true the game is far from perfect, and there are better MMOs out there. It's also true that it is basically a watered-down Borderlands. With the upcoming switch to f2p for the game, as a Deluxe Edition early buyer, I'm more than a bit disappointed, and I feel that loyal players deserve more than what Trion is giving them after this change. It's sad that after already having to buy things in the cash shop from the very beginning, the players that paid 60 dollars for the game still aren't getting completely compensated when all they are giving them are a few extra inventory slots and a few character slots. Character slots should be unlimited for those that bought the game in my opinion, and the game needs to increase its inventory slots overall, because the number you were given pretty much made you want to buy the expansion in the cash shop long before the game went f2p. Now that I got that out of the way and off my chest, I will tell you why this game is very dear to my heart.The TV show is extremely entertaining and is a great show. The events from the game that tie into the show make you feel like you are part of the world's history, and that is a good thing. Furthermore, it is rare to find an MMO with a storyline, and this game does this extremely well using cutscenes. Defiance isn't genre defining, but it's definitely a fresh take on the gameplay from Borderlands, as the first game to be connected with an on-going summer TV series. It's kind of fun to have an MMO version of Borderlands, which I always felt like Borderlands felt like an MMO without players. The game has had a few glitches here-and-there, but nothing really game-breaking has ever occured in the many-many hours I've spent playing this game. The characters in this game are charming and memorable, which is more than you could say for the characters in the vast majority of MMOs. The cutscenes allow characters to express personality, and the voice actors do a good job of breathing life into the NPCs. As far as MMOs go, I could see if the hate towards this game was because of the always-existing cash shop, but most of the hate seems to be directed at the gameplay. The gameplay is not bad, it just needs a tad bit more polish. This game is worth giving a chance. While it may not be for everyone, enough players have fallen in love with the game's charm to allow it to survive this long despite the struggle to keep players interested. The TV show is doing fairly well, and hopefully by going f2p, this will allow people to experience the game and see what has charmed so many people into sticking with a game that often gets more negative reviews than it deserves. The game sets out what it intended to do for the most part, but as of right now, there are no incentives to play as the other races, so hopefully specialty missions will be added in the future. If you only intend to play through the story of the game, you have nothing to lose. It isn't a bad game, and deserves more love than it gets.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												TL;DR:  Worth picking up if you find it on sale.This game pleasantly surprised me.  I managed to pick it up on Steam Summer Sale for 50% off.  It gets -slightly- repetitive while levelling, but no where near as much as most MMO / Grindfests.  It mixes MMO / 3rd-Person Shooter exceptionally well, and it doesn't try to force you to work with people (you can run through the entire storyline solo).  It's multiplayer offers several different modes of PvP combat, Co-Op missions, and a Rift-Like system called "Arks".  You are an Ark-Hunter, after all, and choosing to  help your fellow players in these big (sometimes massive) battles is rewarding both visually and inventorily.  Also, Vehicles!  In an mmo.  Summonable, like mounts, but vehicles!  And they act properly like vehicles.  That's almost a miracle.All of that said, this game is still pretty easy to put down.  Despite everything I like about it, I don't think I would be nearly as happy with the game if I had paid full price.  For everything it does that is unique, there are 2 other things copy and pasted from previous MMO's.  I suppose that's to be expected.The characters can be a little dry at times, but the storyline is solid.  Character creation is GREAT for a FPS, and Lacking for an MMO.  Buy it if it's on sale.  It's worth it.  I don't recommend paying full price.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												To be honest overall, this isn't really a bad game in general, though it should still be noted that this WAS a retail game gone to a free-to-play format now but don't let that alarm you, as for me at least the whole "pay to win" concept doesn't exist in this game, unless you count that for looking for flashy and in style from the game itself.However the only main issue I'm really getting from this game overall is some lag issues here and there forcing me to miss most of my shots when they should have been registered client-side as the game seems to think I'm just standing still server-side when I'm actually moving, aiming, and shooting client-side.Besides that and whatnot it wouldn't be a terrible idea to try this game out, however I would at least get far and play the game long enough to understand at least SOME concepts of it before considering on purchasing some of the content this game has to offer such as the season pass, but I still have much to look into the other purchasable content other than simple cosmetics.So yeah no I wouldn't deem this a terrible game just because of some of the lag issues and it's a "bullet-sponge", honestly anyone who's complaining about a game being a "bullet-sponge" more than likely only has the poor tastes along the generic lines of battlefield and/or CoD which still just essentially and sadly reskin, remodel, and reuse the same things under a new cover.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												So many bugs...The game itself is pretty great, considering that it is based off a mediocre scifi-series that got canceled long ago, one would expect worse. The battles are fun, there is always something to do, the pay-to-win is not too extreme. However:There are countless bugs which utterly ruin this game and which remain unfixed. The helpdesk shows that they are always overloaded with tickets from players apparently.The bugs range from annyoing to completely game-breaking:- Particularly in open dungeons such as bases and mines the enemies will only spawn with 30 and more second of delays. It is entirely possible to have half-explored an outpost just to find oneself suddenly surrounded by enemies- During big battles particularly when lots of action is going on and many objects (mobs and players) are on-screen the engine will suddenly stop displaying anything dynamic. Only the architecture of the map will be shown. It is therefore impossible to avoid damage from mobs or to revive other fallen players as they simply do not show up at all. The sounds show a battle still going on and the minimap shows everything, but its invisible on the main screen- There is a rather late quest in the main quest line which requires to speak to an NPC near a mine. The NPC could be seen walking around from far away (50m or so) but approaching it made it dissapear. Restarting the quest did not change anything, neither did waiting for less traffic on the server. Such a quest-stopping bug after 4 years on the market is frankly intolearble.- there are many more annyoing bugs but these were just the ones that came to my mind right now.I would like to add that these technical bugs are unrelated to the hardware of my computer. I have an i7, 32GB of ram and a GTX950.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2013
												The game is not bad. I played it for 10 hours.As a sniper/assault rifle.The quests are a bit samey, but ok as they are at least in different areas each time.It is nice that as a sniper, I can 1 hit kill with head shots.But I notice your guns never seem to get any more powerful, but enemies progressively take more shots. When I stopped, those e-rep people took 4 head shots to put down, that excessive when there is like 20 of them shooting at you. Or an entire clip from the assault rifle per bad guy. That's extremely excessive for a shooting game.And cover is useless, that's a big flaw. You can pretty easily be shot through cover, and you can't shoot from cover. Your shot often seems to just hit the cover in front of you.So I end up just standing in the open shooting everything, then running to cover and hoping my shields recharge before the bad guys are on me.But then grenades and bazookas ruin that strategy. So I end up "extracting" over and over.It would be nice if this game had greater numbers, but less required shots to put them down. And make cover actually work properly.Simple fixes but they would improve the game immensely.Also, I have trouble paying for the game. We know they have already had lay offs, how much longer is this company going to survive? How much longer will this game survive? I am a casual player, some time on weekends only and only in the fall and spring. And maybe an hour each night. So I want the game to last long enough for me to play it fully and get my value for the money, and I don't think I will be able to. Think of it like a broken Mass Effect, a cover shooter where cover doesn't work, guns don't get stronger, enemies don't understand cover and the RPG elements are minimal at best.On the plus side, the combat is way better than say, star trek online ground combat.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2013
												I played AMB 3 (Advanced Mission Beta 3 or whatever) and I have come to say I like it, yet not. Here are some things below that I think need changing...Bug FixesFIXED >> * When you restore functionality to each secondary radio tower (KTAM East, West, South) you fall from the sky after the cutscene.* Sometimes, bullets don't hit targets. (Especially noticeable with manual sniper rifles.)* Sometimes, shots that should be missed, hit.Things to Improve* Textures. They look okay for mid-HD range, but not high-end HD (1080p+) range where they can have washed out edges, etc.* The sun. It's basically a blurry blob when at the edges of the horizon.* Render Distance of players and enemies. I don't like how enemies and players look like they're slo-mo / lagging at large distances. That said, sniper rifles are useless when trying to see enemies far off, because the render distance for entities is so low.* Culling. Get rid of it.* Enemy AI Line of sight. It pains me to note that cloaking gets rid of aggro, yet going behind buildings doesn't reduce aggro when alone at all. Come on guys, we aren't Minecraft.Things to add* Unique skills / etc. for each class chosen. For instance, the machinist could have an activated skill that places a dispenser of sorts similar to that of Team Fortress 2 so that players don't have to go all the way to the nearest ammo refill point. Veterans could have a passive that makes them better at LMG spread (more accuracy) without the need for perks.* An auction house system to trade directly from scrip to bits and vice versa. As well as an auction house to bid / buy out items / mods, etc. The AH would be a stand-alone EGO via a holographic emitter of sorts in each major NPC village (including the starting one near the crash site.)* An explicit mod attachment tutorial.
